comments.text:
I went to 2 public schools in Alabama and, you could get any drug you could 
think of there. People were selling meth,lsd(fake),codeine, and painkillers 
in the bathroom and the lunchroom.(the only drug I can think that wasn't 
there was heroine) Getting pot was as easy as going to a vending machine. 
There were 80 people in my graduating class I think 50 to 60 smoked pot 
and, the person who finished top of are class was smoked pot almost 
everyday.(It shouldnt matter but there was only 2 black kids and 10 
Hispanics in my graduating class.)﻿

comments.author: Adam Wood

comments.text:
I find it rather unlikely to ever witness another REPUBLICAN presidency in 
my lifetime. Anyone denying the lackluster in mainstream appeal of right 
wing politics is either ignorant or dishonest. The party recently known as 
supporting a default of the United States, pushing for elimination of 
virtually all female reproductive rights and suppressing the vote is hardly 
the "great force" America seeks for leadership. Working to secure benefits 
and hand outs for the top earners somehow doesn't seem to do the 99% much 
good at all. Religious zealots and aging racists/homophobes (the average 
Fox News viewer and Mega Church attendee) can guarantee a solid 25%; far 
short of a percentage required to elect a President! Sorry, but the GOP is 
DOA. It's OVER!﻿

comments.author: Hezekiah Ramirez

comments.text:
I love it. O,Reilly sits there,interrupting her time after time,and then 
has the temerity  to say " you clearly don't want to engage in this 
conversation". Last I looked a conversation was defined as a dialogue 
between two or more people. Talking to yourself is not a 
conversation.O'Reillys body language speaks volumes. too. He always has his 
hands up ,almost like he's being held up. Thats a very clever but 
transparent ploy.He's saying, "Hey I'm willing to listen to your point of 
view"  and at the same time the hands also are a shield and clear 
indication that he would never ever ever actually engage in a real 
conversation unless the muppett he was talking to mirrored his own view. He 
is a really nasty piece of work in every respect.He really ought to think 
about going now because he's looking more and more like the pathetic figure 
he is and guests are no longer intimidated or scared to fight the bully 
back.﻿

comments.text: +A B True dat AB!
comments.author: Chris Stonehouse

comments.text:
+Chris Stonehouse Indeed it doesn't.  They should've thrown all those bank 
CEOs in prison and thrown away the key.
comments.author: A B

comments.text:
+A B No, you're right. This was the old Alan Greenscan line that dominated 
world banking policy in the 90s and Naughties. However, of course it got 
proved totally and utterly wrong. The more you risk... the more chance of 
huge returns. And... if something goes wrong... not only have these people 
proven to be above the law... they all get govt bailouts... and use that 
money to pay themselves extra big fat bonuses. So... big risk + win = huge 
profits. big risk = loose = bailout money/ huge profits. The fact that they 
completely and utterly fucked over every other person on the planet 
wouldn't even come into their thinking.
comments.author: Chris Stonehouse

comments.text:
+Chris Stonehouse The reason why Libertarians don't want bank regulations 
is the belief that Government regulation, and therefore "backing," gives 
them a safety net to do things like risky credit default swaps instead of 
the threat of failing and having no bailout at all.  If the banks knew they 
were responsible for themselves, they wouldn't engage in such risky 
business.
comments.author: A B

comments.text: +Michael Johnson No. But all the best anyway.
comments.author: Chris Stonehouse

comments.text:
+Chris Stonehouse​ Not really. I think maybe you need to go back and read 
what was said in this exchange. It seems like you are confusing this 
discussion with another you were having.
comments.author: Michael Johnson

comments.text:
+Michael Johnson You're obsessed with guns. Which is boring. But I haven't 
made any personal attacks against you... though you've started to get a 
little personal.
comments.author: Chris Stonehouse

comments.text:
It was one analogy you got bent out of shape about. +Chris Stonehouse​ Not 
sure where the rancor is coming from but if you don't wish to converse no 
one is forcing you to. The position seems to be got button for you since we 
were having a pheasant exchange which turned suddenly colorful and hostile 
like flipping a switch.
comments.author: Michael Johnson

comments.text:
+Michael Johnson ???? You seem to spend an abundant amount of time thinking 
about what I think about things. Personally? Lol... no. I just find your 
whole gun-thing boring. Not offensive, boring. But you know, whatever rocks 
your boat.
comments.author: Chris Stonehouse

comments.text:
+Chris Stonehouse​ Not even sure what that means. You seem to have trouble 
with analogies and to take comments very personally.
comments.author: Michael Johnson

comments.text:
+Michael Johnson I'm a non-Democrat too Michael. To me though there's more 
to life than shooting your gun in the air and shouting 'PEW! PEW! PEW!' 
BORING!!! There are more important things going on... but you seem to be 
obsessed with em.
comments.author: Chris Stonehouse

comments.text:
+Chris Stonehouse​ you seem to get frustrated whenever I don't conform to 
your assumptions about non democrats.
comments.author: Michael Johnson

comments.text: O'Reilly is no conservative, he's a neo-con.......and a chicken hawk.
comments.author: W. Blueman

comments.text:
+Michael Johnson Bouncing topics? You're the one bouncing around to gun 
control. I couldn't give a fuck about it. If Americans want to kill 
themselves (and other Americans) with guns... have at it.
comments.author: Chris Stonehouse

comments.text: Absolutely true..for lack of a more succinct phrase.
comments.author: R Schlessel

comments.text:
+Chris Stonehouse​ Not sure what you are referring to specifically. You 
have sort of bounced topics a bit. Politically speaking I think we should 
start with the low hanging fruit. Gun control has no political support and 
is an enforcement nightmare. Decriminalization is already a tend, we have 
evidence it works well and would fundamentally change law enforcement for 
the better.
comments.author: Michael Johnson

comments.text:
+Michael Johnson Trying to bring some small measure of fairness to the 
system isn't misbehaving Michael. It's doing the 'stand up' thing for you 
and your country.
comments.author: Chris Stonehouse

comments.text:
+Chris Stonehouse​ you are stuck in an us vs them mind set. I don't think 
the Rich or lobbyists should be social engineering with tax code either. I 
think they are wrong for doing it. But I can't make myself believe that 
because they are bad I should misbehave.
comments.author: Michael Johnson

comments.text:
+Michael Johnson Always interesting to hear your point of view, but I think 
what you're saying is built on a faulty premise. The US is already being 
socially engineered... by the mega-rich and their lobbyists. They largely 
control both houses, the courts, the media etc. Any organised 'social 
engineering' to slightly reduce the wealth gap would be a drop in the 
bucket. And no one is suggesting taxes that are de-incentivising. The truth 
is... the very wealthy don't really pay any tax and they get all sorts of 
grants, bailout money, incentivation taxpayer money etc etc. What they used 
to call 'the rich man's dole'.
comments.author: Chris Stonehouse

comments.text:
+Chris Stonehouse​ It is a distortion if we compare homicide rates with 
guns in the UK to total deaths in the US. And I agree the US version of 
capitalism is feral and needs to be fixed. My point is that I am not sure 
tax code should be punitive. Rich people do have a larger carbon foot 
print, do use the roads more, have more protection by police and greater 
insurance by FDIC so they should pay more. But tax code as a form of social 
engineering troubles me. We shouldn't incentivize with taxes, nor should we 
punish and we actually do both.
comments.author: Michael Johnson

comments.author: RogerGT

comments.text:
I quite enjoyed your coverage right up until you implied that angry people 
talking over each other is distinctive of people with conservative 
opinions. That's just bullocks. Angry people talking over each other is 
distinctive of angry people. Non-conservative people are not less inclined 
to deal with those arguments more politely by virtue of their 
non-conservativeness. 

You're buying to the bias between American ideologies. Don't be that guy.﻿
comments.author: Niix Starkyller

comments.text:
It's distinctive of most conservative, publicized debates on TV. For two 
reasons- in America you have to be crazy to get people to notice you, so 
it's the crazy radicals that normally get the most coverage, which have 
slowly morphed to become the face of the entire party (true for liberals as 
well). Also, they think that to make debates interesting for the people 
watching, they have to be shouting and disagreeing about something, because 
otherwise your average American won't find it interesting to watch- 
basically part of a PR stunt. Which, sadly, may be true.
